use: Lucius Malfoy's walking stick is an ornamental cane and heirloom of the Malfoy family. Most noticeably, however, it was owned and used by Lucius Malfoy. The cane itself is coated in shiny black lacquer. At the top of the stick is a silver snake's head, which has green crystal eyes. The snake's head is actually the handle of his wand, which is hidden inside the stick.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film)

name: Luna Lovegood's Eagle Hat
use: The eagle hat was a magical hat created by Luna Lovegood to show her support for the Ravenclaw Quidditch team when her team was playing against the Gryffindor Quidditch team at Hogwarts. On top of the hat was what appeared to be a living eagle, which flapped its wings.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance

name: Luna Lovegood's Lion-Topped Hat
use: The lion hat was an enchanted had that was created by Luna Lovegood. She wore it to show her support for the Gryffindor Quidditch team whenever they played against the Slytherin Quidditch team. When she tapped the hat with her wand, it let out an extremely realistic roar.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

name: Lunascope
owners: Albus Dumbledore, Perpetua Fancourt, Newt Scamander, Gnarlak
use: A Lunascope was an astronomical instrument invented by Perpetus Fancourt, which showed the phases of the moons. It was created to counter the difficulty of using Moon chart.
appearances: Harry Potter an the Prisoner of Azkaban, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them: The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

name: MACUSA Real-Time Hex Indicator Map
owners: Magical Congress of the United States of America (MACUSA)
use: The MACUSA Real-Time Hex Indicator Map was used to track the casting of hexes across the United States of America.
appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

name: Magic Lantern
use: A magic lantern was a magical lantern that was enchanted to produce light, without the need for being powered by fuel or electricity
appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first appearance)

name: Magical Exposure Threat Level Measurer
owners: Magical Congress of the United States of America (MACUSA)
use: This measurer was a magical device used in the United States of America that measured the threat level of exposure of magic to the No-Maj people. It hung in the central foyer of the Magical Congress of the United States of America. It resembled a barometer, had four faces, and black hands. Various colours indicated the threat levels: Zero Threat (Green), Level One: Low Threat (Green), Level Two: Moderate Threat (Green), Level Three: High Alert (Blue),Level Four: Danger (Yellow), Level Five: Severe: Unexplained Activity (Orange),Level Six: Emergency (Red). There were also counters indicating how many witch hunts have ocurred, how many times witches and wizards had been exposed, and how many times the Memory Charm had been used on non-magical persons. If the wizarding community in America was close to exposure, the device sounded an alarm informing the Aurors of the impending threat.
appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them: The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

name: Magical Megaphone
owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry
use: A magical megaphone was similar to a Muggle megaphone, except instead of being powered by electricity, it is bewitched with an Amplifying Charm or similar spell to amplify the user's voice much louder than the Muggle version.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

name: Magical Tape Measurer
use: Magical tape measures are measuring devices that are capable of moving of their accord, so that the owner may perform other tasks while taking measurements
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance)

name: Magics Hydrometer
use: A Magic Hydrometer is, presumably, a magical version of an alcoholmeter, a tool used to determine the alcohol proof of a beverage
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film) (first appearance)

name: Metamorph Medal
use: Metamorph Medals were magical objects supposedly to help the wearer metamorphose. These are actually scam objects; they made the wearer turn orange, or in worst cases, causes the wearer to break out in tentacle-like warts.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first mentioned)

name: Gringotts' Mine Cart
use: A Gringotts' Mine Cart was used to transport customers between the vaults of Gringotts Wizarding Bank. Only goblins employed at Gringotts bank could operate these and had special places for lanterns. They moved on specially laid tracks at the bank and were magically operated.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first mentioned0, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

name: Ministry of Magic Fleet of Cars
use: The Ministry of Magic owned a fleet of cars, for the transportation of Ministry officials and their luggage. The Ministry bought the cars from Muggle manufacturers sometime in the twentieth century and later modified them with 'various useful charms' in order to increase their interior capacity and to be able to slide through gaps that non-enchanted cars would not be able to manage.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince

name: Mirror of Erised
owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry
use: The Mirror of Erised was a magical mirror, which, according to Albus Dumbledore, shows the 'deepest, most desperate desire of our hearts.' The name 'Erised' is 'desire' spelled backwards, as if reflected in a mirror. The happiest and most satisfied person in the world would look in the mirror and see a reflection of them, exactly as they were, for they would then have no one and nothing more to yearn or desire for that the mirror could ever show them. But of course, it is intrinsically inherent for human nature to desire something greater than one's own self - meaning that an event wherein the mirror fails to carry out its intended purpose rarely, if at all, happens.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (appears in flashback(s)), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (flashback on disc 2)

name: Moleskin Pouch
use: Mokeskin pouch was a kind of small magical bag made of Mokeskin that was used for storing items, which no one but the owner could get out. It appeared small on the outside, but an enchantment allowed it to have much greater carrying capacity than any non-magical pouch of comparable size.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first appearance)

name: Mad-eye Moody's Trunk
use: Mad-Eye Moody's trunk was a heavily bewitched magical trunk owned by Alastor Moody
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

name: House of Black Music Box
use: The House of Black owned an enchanted music box which would lull the listener to sleep with a sinister, tinkling tune. Members of the Order of the Phoenix came across this box whilst cleaning 12 Grimmauld Place, with Ginny Weasley closing the box before she and several others fell asleep.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

name: Nicolas Flamel's Card
owners: Nicolas Flamel (previously), Albus Dumbledore (previously), Newton (Newt) Scamander
use: This card was a magical piece of chard that contained directions to the Flamel House via an enchanted arrow on the paper
appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crime of Grindelwald (film) (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

name: Nicolas Flamel's Crystal Ball
use: Nicolas Flamel's crystal ball was an orb that let Nicolas see the future
appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

name: Oliver Wood's Quidditch Diagrams
use: During his time as Captain of the Gryffindor Quidditch team, Oliver Wood used a number of diagrams to show new maneuvers and tactics to his team. These diagrams could be animated with the tap of a wand to further showcase the moves in question.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only)

name: Omnioculars
owners: Harry Potter, Ron Weasley, Hermione Granger
use: Omnioculars were the wizarding equivalent of Muggle binoculars, but with the additional features of being able to magically slow down ad replay action
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

name: Orrery
use: Orreries were models of the sun, planets and moons of the solar system, used for studying Astronomy. Sybill Trelawney used one of all nine planets (including Pluto) while teaching Astrology during Divination in 1995.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film) (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance)

name: Owl Lecturn
owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry
use: The Owl Lecturn[3] was an owl-shaped magical podium located in the Great Hall at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry,[1] that dated back to at least the late 1800s.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (non-canonical)

name: Pensieve
use: The Pensieve was a magical device used to review memories. It had the appearance of a shallow stone or metal basin, into which runes and strange symbols were carved and precious stones were fitted. It was filled with a silvery substance that appears to be a cloudy liquid/gas; the collected memories of people who had siphoned their recollections into it.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film) (appears in flashback(s)), Harry Potter and th Deathly Hallows: Part 2

name: Perkin's Tent
owners: Perkins, Weasley family (formerly), Hermione Granger, Harry Potter
use: Perkins, who worked with Arthur Weasley in the Misuse of Muggle Artefacts Office, owned a tent that is charmed to be larger on the inside than it appears to be on the outside, most likely with the Undetectable Extension Charm.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film)

name: Philosopher's Stone
use: The Philosopher's Stone was a legendary alchemical substance with magical properties. This ruby-red stone could be used to create the Elixir of Life, which made the drinker immortal, as well as transform any metal into pure gold. The only known Stone to have ever existed was created by the famed alchemist Nicolas Flamel.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (mentioned only), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

name: Phoenix Fire Lighters
use: Phoenix Fire Lighters is a magical brand of firelighters which, according to the information printed on the box, creates eternal fire. Molly Weasley kept a box of these fire lighters at The Burrow in the 1990s.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance)

name: Potter Memorial
use: The Potter Memorial commemorated James and Lily Potter and also included  dedication to Harry Potter
appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first appearance)

name: Prophecy Record
use: Prophecy Records are used to keep track of prophecies made by Seers.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only)

name: Quick-Quotes Quill
use: A Quick-Quotes Quill was a magical quill that wrote automatically as the subject spoke. However, the quill did not record verbatim what the subject said, but rather took a subject's words and created sensational and inaccurate tales that bore little resemblance to actual events.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (seen on disc 2), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film) (seen on book cover

name: Rainbow Bath Taps
owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry
use: Rainbow Bath Taps[2] were hundreds of enchanted golden bath taps that were fitted in the Prefects' Bathroom at Hogwarts Castle.[2][1] Each of these taps ran their own differently coloured and treated bathwater and bubble baths, each with different fragrances and remedies, providing students with a relaxing experience in the special bath.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

name: Remembrall
use: A Remembrall is a magical large marble-sized glass ball that contains smoke which turns red when its owner or user has forgotten something. It turns clear once whatever was forgotten is remembered.
appearances: Harry Potter an the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only)

name: Resurrection Stone
owners: Cadmus Peverell, Generations of Guants, Marvolo Guant, Morfin Guant, Tom Riddle, Albus Dumbledore, Harry Potter
use: The Resurrection Stone was one of the fabled Deathly Hallows. In The Tale of the Three Brothers, it was the second Hallow created, supposedly by Death himself. It was bestowed upon Cadmus Peverell after he requested, as his bounty, something with the power to recall loved ones from Death. According to legend, whoever reunited it with the other two Hallows (the Elder Wand and the Cloak of Invisibility) would become the Master of Death. It was one of the two Hallows known to have been successfully passed down from generation to generation since Cadmus's time. In 1943 it passed to the possession of Tom Riddle who unknowingly stole it while it was still concealed in Marvolo Gaunt's Ring, which he turned into a Horcrux. The ring was destroyed in 1996 by Albus Dumbledore, but the stone was placed in Harry Potter's first Golden Snitch until it passed into the possession of Harry Potter who used it to great success in the Second Wizarding War.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first identified as the Resurrection Stone, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film) (appears in flashback(s)), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2

name: Revealer
use: A Revealer was a magical device used to render invisible writing visible. It had the appearance of an ordinary Muggle eraser, although it had a bright red color.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance)

name: Rogue Bludger
owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft or Wizardry
use: The rogue bludger's goal was to assault and injure Harry Potter during a Quidditch match
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)

name: Ronald Weasley's Wireless Radio
use: Ronald Weasley used his wireless radio to try to tune into Potterwatch for weeks until he figured out the password, 'Albus'.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film)

name: Rotating Tower
use: A Rotating tower is a tall device divided in several stacked sections. The sections magically rotate on top of each other. The purpose of this device is unknown.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film) (appears in flashback(s)), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

name: Self-correcting Ink
use: Self-Correcting Ink was a type of ink that presumably magically changes whatever was written with it to be correct. used of this ink was banned during exams from the Wizarding Examinations Authority, such as Ordinary Wizarding Levels.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first mentioned)

name: Self-Inking Quill
use: A Self-Inking Quill was a tpe of quill that probably inked itself.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Half Blood Prince

name: Self-Knitting Needles
use: Self-Knitting Needles are a special type of wizarding knitting needles imbued with a charm to make them knit on their own
appearances: Harry Potter and the CHamber of Secrets (film)

name: Self-Operating typewriters
owners: Magical Congress of the United States of America (MACUSA)
use: Self-operating typewriters were machines used for typing on pieces of paper. Self-operating typewriters were enchanted to work automatically without needing someone to operate them.
appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them - The Original Screenplay (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

name: Self-Shuffling Playing Cards
use: Self-Shuffling playing cards are charmed to shuffle themselves
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance)

name: Shamrock Hat
use: A Shamrock hat was a green-coloured hat, which was decorated with Irish shamrocks, which were often worn to show support for the Irish National Quidditch team at Quidditch matches.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

name: Sirius Black's Motorbike
owners: Sirius Black (previous owner), Rubeus Hagrid (borrowed only), Harry Potter (owner)
use: This motorbike was a magical motorcycle owned by Harry Potter that previously belonged to his godfather, Sirius Black, which Harry inherited after Sirius was killed by Bellatrix Lestrange during the Battle of the Department of Mysteries. It had a large engine (suggested by the noise made when active and the fact that it could carry a sidecar). It also appeared to have a kickstart.[1] Magic made it much larger than when it was manufactured, emitting a very loud roar. When Hagrid, a half-giant, rode it, the motorbike was large enough to fit him and could still carry an ordinary-sized person in its sidecar. Another spell made it able to fly fast enough to compete with a broomstick.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film)

name: Sirius Black's Penknife
use: Sirius Black's penknife had attachments designed to open any lock and untie any knot, even if they have been protected against the Unlocking Charm or similar spells. To use the device to open a locked door, one inserted its blade into the crack between door and door frame, then slide it up and down. However, there are some doors that cannot be opened by this knife, such as the door to the Love Chamber in the Department of Mysteries. That particular lock caused the blade to melt.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

name: Slughorn's Hourglass
use: The hourglass' sand ran accordingly with the quality of the conversation: if stimulating, the sand ran slowly.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

name: Spectrespecs
use: Spectrespecs were large, colorful spectacles that were given away free in an issue of The Quibbler in 1996. They were described as making their wearer look like a 'demented, multicolored owl.' They made wrackspurts (invisible creatures that floated through one's ears causing their brain to go fuzzy) visible to the wizarding eye, according to Luna Lovegood.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

name: Sum-Solving Ink
use: Sum-solving ink was a type of ink that presumably helped solve mathematical problems. Luna Lovegood owned a bottle of turquoise sum-solving ink, but someone took it from her and hid it during the 1995–1996 school year, prompting her to post a notice asking for the return of it and several other missing possessions.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (first mentioned) (mentioned on a poster)

name: Sweeper
use: Sweepers, used to clean, consisted of a metal body with a large bag attached to the back and a hoover head at the front, as well as several limbs ending in a variety of brushes and dusters. Sweepers moved autonomously on two wheels and could lift their arms from the ground to clean raised surfaces or people. They bore a heavy resemblance to non-magical vacuum cleaners.
appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

name: Cave Boat
use: This boat was used to get to the island in the middle of the lake in the Horcrux cave, where the locket Horcrux was hidden
appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (appears in vision(s))

name: Time Turner
owners: Hermione Granger (formerly), Albus Dumbledore, Minerva McGonagall, British Ministry of Magic (destroyed)
use: A Time-Turner was a magical device used for time travel. It was a special timepiece which resembled an hourglass on a necklace.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only)

name: Two-Way Mirror
owners: James Potter, Sirius Black, Harry Potter, Mundungus Fletcher, Aberforth Dumbledore
use: A two-way mirror was one in a pair of mirrors that were magically connected. This allowed people to communicate with each other whilst in different locations.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

name: Underwater Viewing Scope
use: An Underwater Viewing Scope was a magical device used to see underwater.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film) (cut content)

name: Vanishing Cabinet
owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, Borgin and Burkes
use: A pair of Vanishing Cabinets would act as a passage between two places. If an object had been placed in one, it would appear in the other.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Par 2 (film) (appears in flashback(s))

name: Veil
owners: British Ministry of Magic, Department of Mysteries
use: The Veil was an enigmatic structure located in the Department of Mysteries. It seemed to be a manifestation of the barrier between the land of the living and the land of the dead. One could not travel freely between the two worlds, as it was a one-way trip. The Unspeakables who worked in the Department of Mysteries likely studied it closely.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (mentioned only)

name: Walls Pretending to be Doors
use: There exist walls that pretend to be doors withing Hogwarts Castle, which annoy first year students trying to find their way around
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first mentioned)

name: Wand Weigher
use: This was a brass instrument used to identify a wand's length, core material, and the length of time it has been used
appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance)

name: Weasley Clock
use: The Weasley Clock was a magical clock owned by the Weasley family which individually monitored each of their whereabouts. Located in the living room at The Burrow, the clock had nine golden hands, one for every member of the household.In place of hours on the clock's face were a series of possible locations, including 'home,' 'school', 'work', 'travelling', 'lost', 'hospital', 'prison', and 'mortal peril.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film

name: Winged Keys
use: The Winged Keys, also known as Flying Keys, were keys that were enchanted with the Flying charm by Professor Filius Flitwick to guard the Philosopher's Stone.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appeared), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)

name: Wireless
use: A wireless, also referred to as a radio, is an audio sound broadcasting service and a form of long-distance communication and entertainment in the wizarding world. Unlike the Muggle variation, it is powered by magic, not electricity.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

name: Wizard Cracker
use: A Wizard Cracker (also known as a Wizarding Cracker) was a magical kind of Christmas cracker that wizards often gifted to each other around Christmas. It held a small gift inside. Unlike Muggle crackers, Wizard Crackers went off with a bang as loud as a cannon blast, enveloping everyone nearby in a cloud of blue smoke, rather than just a small pop. The gifts in comparison to the Muggle counterpart were often far more unique or genuine in quality, with the hats being as durable as the real thing, and the gifts being rather peculiar.
appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

name: Wizard's Checkers
use: Wizard's Checkers was presumably a board game similar to draughts and played between two players using white and black circular pieces.
appearances: Fantastic Beats and Where to Find Them (film)
